Death and Damagesec:death
The GM is the final arbiter of who lives and dies in the game. However these decisions are not made in a vacuum. The GM should understand the expectations of the players about the lethality of the campaign. It is perhaps best if the GM discusses campaign lethality with the players before the campaign starts. Whatever lethality is acceptable it behooves the GM to exagerate the lethality of the game to the players while playing in order to maximise suspense. Any decisions about character death should be made with careful consideration and never made arbitrarily or maliciously. If possible delay the outcome to the next session to give you time to think of an alternative result.
There are six game mechanisms by which we handle character death, injury and insanity. They are Hit Points, Fractional Damage, Near Death, Instant Death, Aspects (for phobias, insanity, disease, chronic illnesses and disabilities) and Divine Intervention.
Hit Points
Hit points, that is Stamina and Health, are used to determine the players well-being, mainly during combat and combat-like scenarios. These are scenarios where the player's skill and experience would be pertinent to avoiding injury. Combat is one example of this. Another example might be avoiding poison darts from a trap.
Fractional Damage
Fractional damage occurs to a character when the character suffers damage outside of combat. For example a character that falls off a roof may take two thirds of their total full hit points damage. When calculating fractional damage round down any remainder so that damage is minimized.
Near Death
Once the characters hit points reach zero they gain the Near-Death condition and probably the Down and Prone conditions as well. Each round they roll on the Near Death Table until their situation is resolved; see Tabletable:gmg-near-death-table on page table:gmg-near-death-table. If an effect reduces a character to Near Death then all their hit points are reduced to zero.
Instant Death
There are some situations where the character cannot possibly survive, falling from a great height into a sea of lava. In this case the GM can rule that the character has died instantly. The GM should remember that the characters are supposed to be epic heroes and give them every chance of saving themselves before having them die like this.
Before killing a character outright the GM may consider the following:
Declare an alternate outcome of some sort, or
Negotiating an outcome with the player and the party, or
Ending the session to gain time to ponder the best response at length.
Aspects
One use of aspects is to encode ongoing effects to a character. A character who nearly drowns might gain a hydrophobia aspect. A charcter who falls off a building might gain a crippled aspect. A character with a disease might gain a Coughs aspect. Because these aspects have an ongoing effect on a character the GM should assign them sparingly to characters. We suggest only doing so in the case of banes rolled while saving.
Divine Intervention
Divine intervention is a special rule where the characters last act is to plead for intervention from a God or patron before they die. They make a Std Check with a difficulty of 24, if successful the God intervenes, usually indirectly, on the characters behalf somehow. Particularly religious characters gain a +1 on this roll. If the character has donated to the gods church recently they gain an additional +1. Such intervention, when it happens, is never free of obligation and the god will surely require something in return.

HP only in combat? - hit points are the enemy of narrative. - plot armour. - sword to the throat. - outs!!!
The GM should choose the option that is most reasonable and narratively satisfying. If a character falls into a pool of lava they are dead. If they have been knocked down by Orcs then roll on the Near Death Table.
How should we handle falling, drowning damage etc. In short the answer is don't. Whenever there's a chance of failure in potentially fatal checks like this you're doing it wrong. Establish the potential consequences ahead of time and possible outs. If they fail then their party members might have a chance to save them? Possibly failure just means they can't perform the action (e.g. climb the cliff).

Combat Damage Death see Zero Health Zero Hit Points Banes
We make a distinction between damage dealt to characters within combat, and damage dealt to characters outside of combat. The GM should handle damage dealt within combat using Hit Points and Near Death Rolls. That is, when a character is hit they take the damage from the weapon and they subtract that damage from the characters hit points. A characters Health has a minimum value of zero. When the characters Health is reduced to zero they are Down, and enter a Near Death state.
This does not apply to damage dealt outside of combat, including danger to the character due to things like drowning, falling, fire, poison, assasination, coup de grâce etc. In these situations, hit points are the enemy of the narrative, they kill suspense, and they should not be used. Besides, it makes no sense that a 10th level fighter character should be more resistant to drowning than a 1st level fighter.

Falling Damage
When a character falls the type of damage they receive depends on how far they fall, see Table table:falling on page table:falling-table. The GM should feel free to make allowances for the character slowing their fall, or the surface that the character is landing on as they see fit. For example the characters should be allowed to make a Luck check to see if they fall on something soft or at least not to damaging or perhaps hitting an awning half way down. The characters could make an agility check to see if they are able to grab something to reduce the speed of their fall. Each such success should reduce the fall damage by one tier in the Falling Damage table.
For example, a character falls off the top of a five story building. They make an agility check and hit an awning on the way down. They make a further Luck check and land in a stack of hay.

section.p: Most people can hold their breath for 2 minutes, 12 combat rounds. Beyond that they must start to roll on the Near Death table. Once they can breathe again then they are restored completely. No hit points are lost. If they rolled a bane on any of their death rolls the GM might consider giving them an aspect or a temporary condition.
